thread.section_title: Texas Longhorns News - Sports News for Dallas, Texas
thread.title: Carlton: Streaking Sooners look to add to Texas' historically bad start to season
thread.title_full: Carlton: Streaking Sooners look to add to Texas' historically bad start to season | Dallas Morning News

author: Chuck Carlton
title: Carlton: Streaking Sooners look to add to Texas' historically bad start to season
text:
Fresh from a nice 44-24 win over West Virginia, undefeated Oklahoma moved up to 10th in the AP Top 25 on Sunday.
The installation of the Air Raid offense has Oklahoma averaging 521.8 yards per game. The defense is back to making plays.
After questioning the Sooners' relevancy earlier this season, ESPN personality Paul Finebaum did penance by wearing an OU hat on-air after the Sooners' win at Tennessee.
As the Sooners look ahead to Saturday's AT&T Red River Showdown with Texas at the Cotton Bowl Stadium, OU seem poised to join No. 2 TCU and No. 3 Baylor as real-deal national contenders.
Or the Sooners could be fool's gold, like last season. Oklahoma climbed as high as No. 4 in the AP poll early in the season, then dropped five of their last nine games with embarrassing losses to Baylor and Clemson.
Maybe this is the Oklahoma team everybody expected in 2014, arriving a year late.
ESPN analyst Kirk Herbstreit jumped on the Sooner Schooner early, picking Oklahoma before the season to be one of the four teams in the College Football Playoff.
"I think Oklahoma is going to surprise everybody," Herbstreit said at the time.
Neither coach Bob Stoops nor his players exactly embraced the West Virginia win as a statement game.
"I don't know about that," center Ty Darlington said. "It was definitely a start today, great way to start conference play, but now we've got eight more conference games in a row, so we're going straight down the gauntlet and will have plenty of more opportunities to make statements."
While Oklahoma (4-0, 1-0) enters on a hot streak, Texas (1-4, 0-2) is more of a hot mess. The Longhorns haven't been this bad this early in the season since the Eisenhower Administration. En route to 1-9 finish in 1956, Texas suffered a 45-0 loss to No. 1 Oklahoma.
Texas sits near the bottom of a bunch of national defensive stats. No team in the Bowl Subdivision has allowed more first downs.
Even social media has been a problem. Freshman cornerback Kris Boyd issued an apology through the school Sunday for a halftime Twitter excursion during a 50-7 loss to TCU. The retweet suggested Boyd and fellow freshman Malik Jefferson consider a transfer to Texas A&M.
"In NO way did I intend to be disrespectful or disloyal," Boyd said in part. "I deeply regret my actions and want to reassure everyone that I am 100 [percent] committed to this team and program. ...
"I promise everyone that I will learn and grow from this."
Don't expect Oklahoma to look past Texas, no matter the records.
"Yeah, it's always a game you want to play in as a little kid and now it's finally here," Oklahoma quarterback Baker Mayfield said. "Even with how they're playing right now, you can't go in there and take them lightly."
Just two years ago, with the Mack Brown era on life support, Case McCoy led a 36-20 Texas win over the 12th ranked Sooners that wasn't close.
Even for a team with big ambitions, rivalry games can become roadblocks. And few rivalries match Texas-OU.
"We know they are moving a little slow but every year they are ready for us," Oklahoma linebacker Eric Striker told reporters. "We can't sleep on them.
"That's one team that you know you have to be ready for -- this one."
Three takeaways Three takeaways from this past weekend in the Big 12:
-- Baylor junior quarterback Seth Russell leads the nation in passing efficiency and ranks eighth in total offense (363.3 yards per game).
-- Oklahoma State defensive end Emmanuel Ogbah has 6.5 sacks this season through five games and is tied for fifth nationally. He's been remarkably consistent with 11 sacks in his last 13 games.
-- The 30 points allowed by Texas in the first quarter against TCU was the most since Houston scored 31 on the Longhorns in 1987.
